Incident.Summary: Search Report / Possession of Cannabis - Personal Amount

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
This stop was audibly and visually recorded using the Axon Digital Video System installed in Maryland State Police Vehicle, U-16, as well as my Axon body worn camera.

Location: 924 Costley Way, Prince Frederick, Calvert County, Maryland 20678

Date and Time: 2/14/2023 @ 1328 hours

Narrative:

I used the in car Golden Eagle 2 RADAR unit (Serial #50001377) installed in Maryland State Police Vehicle, U-16, for this stop. The RADAR unit was tested and was functioning properly. I am a certified RADAR/LIDAR operator. That training was received at the Maryland State Police Academy in 2019.

I am certified to complete North American Standard (NAS) Level III inspections on commercial motor vehicles. That training was received through the Maryland State Police Commercial Vehicle Enforcement Division in 2018.

On February 14, 2023, I, TFC Moorman #6980, was on uniformed patrol operating unmarked Maryland State Police Vehicle, U-16. I was traveling South on Solomons Island Road in lane one. I observed a white Ford box truck traveling North on Solomons Island Road in lane one approaching Old Field Lane. I activated my in car Golden Eagle 2 RADAR unit (#50001377) in front facing opposite direction moving mode. I obtained a speed of 65 mph in a posted 45 mph speed zone. The Ford was the only vehicle traveling North at the time I obtained the speed. I observed the Ford did not have a front registration plate attached. I made a U-turn and began traveling North to initiate a traffic stop on the Ford. I positioned my patrol vehicle behind the Ford in the left turn lane at the intersection of Solomons Island Road and Chapline Place Blvd. When the light turned green, the Ford made a left turn onto Chapline Place Blvd as I followed. I identified the registration as, “26S561”/Maryland. I activated my emergency equipment to initiate a traffic stop. The Ford came to a complete stop in the parking lot of 924 Costley Way, Prince Frederick, Maryland.

I made a driver’s side approach and made contact with the driver and sole occupant of the vehicle. I informed the driver for the reason of the traffic stop and informed him I would be completing a NAS Level III inspection on the truck. I identified the driver as, Aston Lee Galbraith Jr, B/M, DOB: 11/19/1992, by his U.S. Passport. Galbraith advised he needed to find the registration and insurance card. Galbraith exited the vehicle and walked to the passenger side to search for the documents. Galbraith opened the passenger side door and I detected the strong odor of burnt Cannabis emitting from the vehicle. Galbraith asked if I needed to search the truck. I asked Galbraith when the last time Cannabis was in the vehicle. Galbraith advised two weeks ago. I requested another unit for assistance and TFC Bauer #6719 responded. Galbraith advised he needed to call the boss of the company to ask where the documents were. I spoke with the owner of the truck, and he advised he would send Galbraith a copy of the insurance information. The owner sent the insurance card and I observed it was for a different vehicle and was expired. I asked the driver if he had a US DOT Medical Examiners Certificate, and he stated he did not. I noted the company name and US DOT number were not displayed on the truck as required. I had Galbraith walk to the front of my patrol vehicle.

I conducted a probable cause search of the Ford. I located one plastic bag containing suspected Cannabis (Weight: 1.7 Grams with packaging) on top of the front passenger seat.

I recognized the item as a Controlled Dangerous Substance, “Suspected Cannabis”, and determined it was a “personal use” amount from my training, knowledge, experience, and previous drug arrests. That training was received at the Maryland State Police Academy in 2019. During that time, I was familiarized with the use and packaging of various Controlled Dangerous Substances to include Marijuana, Synthetic Marijuana, PCP, Heroin, Cocaine, Prescription Medication, MDMA, and Methamphetamine.

I secured the recovered Controlled Dangerous Substance, “Suspected Cannabis”, and stored it in the trunk of my patrol vehicle as evidence.

I relayed Galbraith’s information to the Barrack dispatcher, and they advised his driver’s license through Maryland was suspended for district court fail to comply. The Barrack dispatcher advised the registration, “26S561”/MD returned to a 2006 Chevrolet Van and expired 6/30/2012. I relayed the VIN number for the Ford and the Barrack dispatcher advised the Ford was not registered. I made another driver’s side approach and made contact with Galbraith. Galbraith was speaking with the owner of the Ford on his cellphone. I spoke with the owner of the Ford who advised the Ford was currently uninsured. The owner advised he contacted a tow company, and they were in route for the Ford.

Galbraith was issued a Civil Citation (#0Z46648805), for the Possession of Cannabis – Personal Amount. Galbraith was placed Out of Service for 24 hours for possessing a Controlled Dangerous Substance in a commercial motor vehicle. I spoke with the owner of the company, and he stated the name of the business was "Nexxt moving". The company did not have a US DOT number. Galbraith was issued numerous traffic citations for the traffic stop.

Case closed.

All events occurred in Calvert County, Maryland.

IncidentProperty.Description: One plastic bag containing suspected Cannabis.
